subject: Re: [junit] Integrating rspec and JUnit
msgSnippet: I have not tested this but I just assumed that if you used class-descriptions the IDE runner would know which file to open based on that information... Well,
messageBody:
I have not tested this but I just assumed that if you used
class-descriptions the IDE runner would know which file to open
based on that information... Well, well, what do I know... It would be good
if it worked...

:)

On 9/9/07, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> Actually, I think that while TestRunners work great to extend JUnit,
> they
> interact very poorly with IDE's, which are often hardcoded to understand
> only the main runner and get completely lost when they try to execute a
> custom runner.
>
> --
> Cédric
>
> On Sep 9, 2007 1:02 PM, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...<joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>>
> wrote:
>
> > Thanks, I think so too :)
> >
> > I think that with custom runners JUnit has a good chance to be the
> adapter
> > between a whole host of testing frameworks out there and any tool that
> > runs
> > tests.
> > Since JUnit is supported by most IDE:s (is there any IDE that does not
> > have
> > JUnit support?) there is a lot to win by being JUnit compatible even if
> > it's
> > only for IDE and ant, maven etc support.
> >
> > If I were rolling my own test-framework I would definitely see if I
> could
> > fit my core-edge within the JUnit custom-runner framework and let others
> > worry about eclipse, ant, maven, netbeans, idea,
> > raven and whatever else is out there -support.
> >
> > It will be interesting to see if more "adapters" will be written this
> way
> > in
> > the future. Which one is the next one? TestNG?
> > This custom runner stuff is cool! Keep up the good work!
> >
> >
> > On 9/9/07, David Saff <saff@... <saff%40mit.edu> <saff%40mit.edu>>
> wrote:
> > >
> > > Joakim,
> > >
> > > I think it's really interesting stuff. I'm not currently using Ruby,
> > > but I have built Java / Ruby hybrid systems in the past, and I think I
> > > would use this if I needed to again in the future. I'm also really
> > > glad to see the custom Runner support get a thorough workout.
> > >
> > > David
> > >
> > > On 9/8/07, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...<joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>
> <joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>
> > <joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>>
> > > wrote:
> > > > Hi all, I have been playing with JRuby recently and in particular
> how
> > > > to embed Ruby in Java applications. I believe that mixing languages
> > > > rather than switching completely from one language to another is
> going
> > > > to be more and more important. As I explored the subject i found
> > > > myself lacking some tools. I was frustrated by the fact that I had
> to
> > > > maintain two sets of tests and look for feedback in two different
> > > > locations while developing.
> > > >
> > > > I created a custom runner for JUnit to address the subject and I
> think
> > > > it looks promising. I created a blog entry with some more details in
> > > > case anyone is interested:
> > > >
> > > > http://johlrogge.wordpress.com/2007/09/08/hybrid-theory/
> > > >
> > > > I have some loose plans on open-sourcing this but I would like to
> see
> > > > if there are others than me that find this interesting enough to be
> > > > worth the effort before I do.
> > > >
> > > > /Joakim Ohlrogge
